thread.title: How to complain to a hotel or airline and get what you want

author: Chris Kitching for MailOnline
title: How to complain to a hotel or airline and get what you want
text:
22 shares 19
View
comments
With tourists seemingly more demanding than ever before, it’s not unusual to see heated arguments at the airport check-in counter or hotel reception desk.
While many travellers may be confrontational or turn to Facebook or Twitter to vent, it’s not the best way to resolve a problem with a hotel room that doesn’t live up to expectations, an undesirable plane seat or undercooked meal.
With these tips from etiquette and protocol expert William Hanson, holidaymakers can effectively complain to everyone from hotel managers to flight attendants to ultimately get what they want.
Guests should remain calm and reasonable when they are making a complaint at a hotel reception desk
Deal with it in person
Mr Hanson said the most effective way to make a complaint is in person with staff or a manager, whenever possible.
For example, if there is a problem with a hotel room – be it an uncomfortable bed or a faulty TV – ask a member of staff to come to the hotel room to witness it first-hand.

Holidaymakers booking Airbnb in Paris will be charged a... 22 shares Mr Hanson said he recently stayed at a swanky hotel in China, where guests can switch off the lights in their room by pressing a single button next to the bed.
The button was faulty, so staff fixed it at his request. After he notified staff when the button didn’t work the second night, the hotel upgraded him to a suite and moved all of his belongings to his new room.
He said: ‘It was delightful because something was wrong, there was nothing that could be done about it and I think I was being quite reasonable.’
Be specific
It doesn’t hurt to write down a few notes, including exact dates or times, which can be given to staff while making a complaint.
The more information provided to the employee or manager, the more likely they will be able to assist.
Photos can help as well, especially if something is dirty, broken or faulty.
Remember the names or any staff members who have taken a complaint.
Airline passengers should make sure they have a genuine complaint before approaching staff at the gate
Be reasonable
It’s important to remain calm and be reasonable when speaking to staff, as a confrontation will only make matters worse.
But don’t be too nice and understanding, as you may let the hotel, airline or cruise line off the hook.
Mr Hanson said: ‘The British are programmed to complain in quite a nice way, as opposed to Americans, for example, who make quite a song and dance about it.’
Is it a genuine complaint?
If it is, be firm but fair, said Mr Hanson.
He added: ‘You actually have to have a genuine complaint. There are some people who complain for the sake of complaining.
‘You need to have some just cause to complain and if right is on your side it should be easily rectifiable by whoever you’re complaining to.’
The goal is to get the person on your side, he said.
Explain what you want
Staff may ask what they can do to rectify the problem and satisfy the customer.
Unhappy customers should clearly explain how they expect the employee to resolve the matter.
But they should not make unreasonable requests for free goods or services.
People who work in the service industry should be treated fairly and with respect when making a complaint
Don’t be rude
People who work in the service industry are among the worst-treated employees on the planet.
They deserve to be treated fairly and with respect, as the problem quite often has nothing to do with their actions.
An employee may be less likely to help if they are insulted or talked down to.
Go above their heads
Usually, the first point of contact is a front-line member of staff such as an employee at a hotel’s reception desk, a flight attendant or a restaurant server.
If they fail to understand or resolve the complaint, ask to speak to their manager, said Mr Hanson.
If the traveller still isn’t satisfied, they should write a letter and send it to the manager’s boss.
Mr Hanson said: ‘When you copy it up so that the manager’s manager sees it sometimes that gives the manager a kick up the bottom.
‘Be factual in the letter. End with a sentence or two to let them know how you feel and don’t go on too long. Let the crime speak for itself.’
Holidaymakers who are still unhappy can also complain to industry regulators or organisations such as the Association of British Travel Agents in the UK.
